utterances: Stone hiked into the backcountry to search for the pups.

We would stop every few hundred yards or so and do kind of a muffled howl, a lower howl, and then a little bit louder, in hopes that the pups would respond back to us: especially if they were hiding at that point and still alive.
Years ago, a wolf biologist taught Stone how to howl.
(Soundbite of Suzanne Stone doing wolf howl)
She kept hiking and howling until dark, but the wolf pups didn't respond.
Stone represents Defenders of Wildlife, in Idaho.
She understands that some wolves that eat livestock may have to be killed.
But Stone says leaving the pups on their own was a new low for government wildlife managers.
This was a, you know, miserable way that these animals ended up being handled.
The wolves are still a federally protected species, but because they're thriving in Idaho, the federal government put the state in charge of them in January.
Stone worries that the move is eroding protections for wolves.

It's a signal to us that there's something slipping here and that we need to make sure that wolf conservation is maintained at the same standards that we've had in the past, even though the state is now responsible for managing wolves.
Mr. STEVE NETTO(ph) (Idaho State Conservation Official): We recommend as humane a treatment of these animals as unfortunately mistakes happen.
In Idaho, Steve Netto is the state official in charge of managing wolves.
He ordered the wolves, including the five pups, to be killed.
But he says, the federal trapper who carried out the order was supposed to find the pups first and kill them humanely.
Wildlife experts say, without the parents alive to lead the trappers to the pups, it's almost impossible to find them.
Netto says it's important to remember, that wolves have been reproducing so well in Idaho, that there are 600 of them in the state.
The regrettable loss of a few pups does not have any real biological impact on the recovery and long-term viability of this population.
Gail Kern(ph) is a spokeswoman for Wildlife Services, the federal agency that killed the wolves.
She says two weeks after the parents were killed the agency still has people looking for the pups.

They've been looking for tracks, they've been howling to try to call the wolf pups in, and they've had dogs out in the area to try to sniff out the pups, and they've just been unsuccessful, unfortunately.
Wolf experts say it's very unlikely that the pups are still alive after two weeks on their own.
Elizabeth Shogren, NPR News, Washington.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.

The third of your playlist.
Years ago, if I went after your girlfriend, you and I might have a schoolyard fight or something like that.
That'll be it.
It'll be over.
Nowadays, these kids will shoot each other.
I was jealous.
Here were these kids, different shades and shapes, and they had the nerve to get along with each other, drawn together by one common purpose only: to play.
I wanted in that instant to own that quality, to be a member of their club, to be just like them.
So I decided that's exactly what I would do.
One night I put on my sneakers and sweat pants and my baseball cap and I went to the playground.
As I approached the twisted metal-wood-plastic kingdom my breath was shortened.
I was alone and the park was closed.
For the first time since I was 10 I went to the playground to, well, play.
I climbed the rock wall, tried my best to make my six feet and two inches hang from the monkey bars and slid down that slide.
And yes, I even walked up backwards.
The next morning I sat in a healing muscle mineral bath and reflected on the night's escapade.
Yeah, it was silly.
But I did re-learn that the most important lessons we absorb come from our childhood.
Feel free.
Use your imagination.
Have fun.
Be polite.
Get along.
And if you hurt someone, say I'm sorry.
When did we grown-ups forget those things?
From now on I'm going to try to hold on to the notion that we can all, indeed, get along.

And before I drag my grown behind out of the safe confines of my house to the playground again in the middle of the night, maybe I'll call some friends, and enemies, and ask them if they want to come along and play.
(Soundbite of music)
That was Jeff Obafemi Carr with this week's Snapshot.

Coming up, leaving Congress can lead to all sorts of opportunities, including for lawmakers becoming Washington lobbyists and for New Mexico politicians aspiring for bigger jobs.
First though, to Annapolis, Maryland, where representatives of dozens of countries have gathered to talk about Middle East peace.
President Bush opened the conference by saying the Israelis and the Palestinians would start serious negotiations in two weeks.
The goal: a peace agreement by the end of next year.
